---
title: 'basic Template'
description: 'Minimal story with single default example'
---

## Overview

The `basic` template generates the simplest possible story file with just a default export and one story.

**Use this when:**
- Prototyping or proof of concept
- Simple components with few or no props
- Design system tokens (colors, spacing, typography)
- You want minimal boilerplate

## Generated Output

```tsx Example
import type { Meta, StoryObj } from '@storybook/react'
import { Button } from './Button'

const meta: Meta<typeof Button> = {
  title: 'Components/Button',
  component: Button,
  tags: ['autodocs'],
}

export default meta
type Story = StoryObj<typeof Button>

export const Default: Story = {
  args: {
    children: 'Button',
  },
}
```

## What's Included

<Check>Default meta export with component type</Check>
<Check>Single story with basic props</Check>
<Check>autodocs tag for automatic documentation</Check>

## What's Not Included

<Warning>No variant stories</Warning>
<Warning>No interaction tests</Warning>
<Warning>No accessibility checks</Warning>
<Warning>No responsive examples</Warning>

## When to Use

Perfect for:
- **Quick prototypes** - Get a story up fast to preview a component
- **Simple components** - Stateless components without complex props
- **Design tokens** - Colors, spacing, typography that don't need variants
- **Starting point** - Begin with basic and add features manually

## Example Use Cases

<Tabs>
  <Tab title="Design Tokens">
    ```tsx Color.tsx
    export const Color = ({ name, value }: { name: string; value: string }) => (
      <div>
        <div style={{ background: value, width: 100, height: 100 }} />
        <p>{name}: {value}</p>
      </div>
    )
    ```

    Generated story:
    ```tsx Color.stories.tsx
    export const Default: Story = {
      args: {
        name: 'Primary',
        value: '#FF4785',
      },
    }
    ```
  </Tab>

  <Tab title="Simple Component">
    ```tsx Avatar.tsx
    export const Avatar = ({ src, alt }: { src: string; alt: string }) => (
      <img src={src} alt={alt} style={{ borderRadius: '50%', width: 48, height: 48 }} />
    )
    ```

    Generated story:
    ```tsx Avatar.stories.tsx
    export const Default: Story = {
      args: {
        src: 'https://i.pravatar.cc/150',
        alt: 'User avatar',
      },
    }
    ```
  </Tab>

  <Tab title="Icon Component">
    ```tsx Icon.tsx
    export const Icon = ({ name }: { name: string }) => (
      <span className={`icon-${name}`} />
    )
    ```

    Generated story:
    ```tsx Icon.stories.tsx
    export const Default: Story = {
      args: {
        name: 'home',
      },
    }
    ```
  </Tab>
</Tabs>

## Usage

<CodeGroup>
```json MCP Tool
{
  "componentPath": "src/components/Color.tsx",
  "template": "basic"
}
```

```bash CLI
npx storybook-mcp sync src/components/Color.tsx --template basic
```
</CodeGroup>

## Extending the Template

After generation, you can manually add features:

```tsx Enhanced basic template
import type { Meta, StoryObj } from '@storybook/react'
import { Button } from './Button'

const meta: Meta<typeof Button> = {
  title: 'Components/Button',
  component: Button,
  tags: ['autodocs'],
}

export default meta
type Story = StoryObj<typeof Button>

export const Default: Story = {
  args: {
    children: 'Button',
  },
}

// Manually add more stories
export const WithIcon: Story = {
  args: {
    children: 'Button',
    icon: 'â†’',
  },
}

export const Loading: Story = {
  args: {
    children: 'Loading...',
    disabled: true,
  },
}
```
